questions.text: What is the stimulus used in short-wavelength automated perimetry (SWAP)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • SWAP uses a Size V blue stimulus on a yellow background to selectively stimulate short-wavelength–sensitive pathways, specifically targeting small bistratified ganglion cells.
  • This technique is designed to detect early glaucomatous visual field loss, which typically begins in these pathways before manifesting on standard white-on-white perimetry

SWAP (Short-Wavelength Automated Perimetry)

  • Also called blue-on-yellow perimetry.
  • Stimulus Used:
    • Target: Blue (short-wavelength) stimulus
    • Size: Size V is preferred over Size III because:
      • Blue cones are fewer in number, leading to higher variability with smaller stimuli.
      • Larger stimulus (Size V) improves detection reliability.
    • Background: Yellow background is used to suppress medium- and long-wavelength cone activity, thereby isolating the short-wavelength response.
  • Rationale:
    • SWAP is useful in detecting early glaucoma, especially pre-perimetric glaucoma.
    • It selectively stimulates small bistratified retinal ganglion cells, which are among the earliest affected in glaucoma.
    • Although promising, SWAP is time-consuming and requires expensive equipment and trained personnel, limiting its routine use in screening.

Explanation of other options:

Size III, yellow (Option B): Yellow stimuli are used as background in SWAP, not as targets.

Size V, yellow (Option C): Again, yellow is not used as a stimulus but as a suppressive background to isolate blue cone pathways.

Size III, blue (Option D): Blue stimulus is correct, but Size III is too small, leading to high variability and poor detection accuracy in SWAP.

questions.text: The following substance has a higher concentration in aqueous than in plasma
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lactate has a higher concentration in the aqueous humour than in plasma.

  • The aqueous humour is formed by ultrafiltration of plasma through the ciliary processes, followed by active secretion and diffusion.
  • Although it is derived from plasma, some substances are selectively transported or concentrated during formation.

Concentration Comparison:

  • Higher in aqueous than plasma:
    • Lactate, Ascorbate, Pyruvate (Mnemonic: "ATE more in aqueous")
  • Lower in aqueous than plasma:
    • Protein, Glucose, Urea

Thus, among the options given, lactate is the only substance present in higher concentration in aqueous humour than in plasma.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

Production of Aqueous Humour:

  • Site: Ciliary processes of the pars plicata
  • Lined by 2 layers of epithelium: Pigmented (outer) and Non-pigmented (inner)
  • Steps:
    1. Ultrafiltration of plasma → initial filtrate
    2. Active secretion and diffusion across ciliary epithelium → forms aqueous humour
  • Rate: 2-3 μL/min

Aqueous Outflow Pathways:

  1. Conventional (Trabecular) Pathway - ~90% outflow
    • Trabecular meshwork → Schlemm's canal → Collector channels → Episcleral veins
    • Site of highest resistance: Juxtacanalicular trabecular meshwork
  2. Unconventional (Uveoscleral) Pathway - ~10% outflow
    • Ciliary body → Suprachoroidal space → Sclera → Vortex/Episcleral veins

questions.text: Which of the following processes is not involved in aqueous formation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The formation of aqueous humor involves ultrafiltration, diffusion, and active secretion, but not simple filtration.
  • Filtration, a passive, non-selective process, is not a recognized step; instead, ultrafiltration refers to pressure-dependent selective filtering at the ciliary capillaries.

Aqueous Humor Formation:

  1. Ultrafiltration (Option D ruled out)
    • First step: plasma is ultrafiltered from fenestrated capillaries in the ciliary stroma.
    • Driven by hydrostatic pressure.
    • It's a selective process, unlike general filtration.
  2. Diffusion (Option A ruled out)
    • Passive movement of small, lipid-soluble molecules across concentration gradients.
    • Helps transfer plasma components into the aqueous.
  3. Active Secretion (Option B ruled out)
    • Primary mechanism (responsible for ~95% of aqueous volume).
    • Powered by ATP-dependent transport of ions (mainly Na⁺ and HCO₃⁻) by nonpigmented ciliary epithelium.
    • Tight junctions in these cells maintain the blood-aqueous barrier.
    • Also actively secretes ascorbic acid and lactic acid.

Related important points and concepts:

  • Aqueous humor is low in protein, glucose, and urea compared to plasma.
  • Higher levels of ascorbic acid and lactic acid are seen due to secretion and metabolic activity (esp. of the lens).
  • Maintains IOP, provides nutrients to the lens and cornea, and contributes to waste removal.

questions.text: The site of production of aqueous humour is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aqueous humour is produced by the non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary processes in the pars plicata of the ciliary body.

These cells actively secrete aqueous into the posterior chamber, using energy-dependent transport mechanisms.

Site of Production:

  • The pars plicata is the anterior portion of the ciliary body containing the ciliary processes.
  • These are lined by a double-layered epithelium:
    • Outer (toward stroma): Pigmented
    • Inner (facing aqueous): Non-pigmented
  • The non-pigmented epithelium is the active site of aqueous secretion.

Mechanism:

  1. Ultrafiltration: Plasma filtrate enters the stroma from the capillaries.
  2. Diffusion: Small molecules passively move across membranes.
  3. Active Secretion: Ions (mainly Na⁺ , Cl⁻, HCO₃⁻) are secreted by non-pigmented epithelial cells → draws water osmotically into the posterior chamber.

Explanation of other options:

Non-pigmented ciliary process of pars plana(Option A): Pars plana is not involved in aqueous secretion.

Pigmented ciliary process of pars plana(Option C): Pigmented layer does not actively secrete aqueous; also, pars plana is anatomically inactive in aqueous production.

Plasma (Option D): Aqueous humour is derived from plasma, but it is not produced in the plasma itself.

questions.text: Cells affected in Glaucomatous Optic Neuropathy are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glaucoma primarily leads to the degeneration and death of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and their axons. These axons form the nerve fiber layer and ultimately the optic nerve, and their progressive loss is the hallmark of glaucomatous optic neuropathy.

Glaucomatous Optic Atrophy:

It refers to the degenerative changes in the optic nerve head resulting from chronic loss of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and their axons, typically due to raised intraocular pressure (IOP) in glaucoma.

Pathophysiology:

  • Primary event: Progressive death of RGCs through apoptosis, triggered by:
    • Mechanical stress from increased IOP → compression at the lamina cribrosa
    • Vascular insufficiency → ischemia
    • Excitotoxicity → excessive glutamate
    • Oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and inflammatory cytokines
  • Result: Loss of axons leads to cupping of the optic disc, thinning of the nerve fiber layer, and eventual visual field defects.

Histopathological Features:

  • Loss of nerve fibers in the optic nerve
  • Reactive gliosis
  • Thinning of the neuroretinal rim on imaging (OCT)

Clinical Signs (Fundus):

  • Increased cup-to-disc ratio (normal ≤0.3)
  • Vertical elongation of the optic cup
  • Pallor of the neuroretinal rim in advanced stages
  • Bayonetting and nasalization of blood vessels
  • Disc hemorrhages (sometimes seen in normal-tension glaucoma)

Visual Field Defects: Typically arcuate scotomas, nasal steps, or peripheral constriction - these correlate with the pattern of RGC axon loss.

Important Points:

  • Glaucomatous optic atrophy is the end stage of chronic glaucoma.
  • The process is irreversible - early detection is critical.
  • It may occur with normal IOP in normal-tension glaucoma.
  • Ganglion cell death continues even after normalization of IOP due to neurodegenerative mechanisms.

Explanation of other options:

Bipolar cells (Option A): Bipolar cells are interneurons in the retina that transmit signals from photoreceptors (rods and cones) to ganglion cells. They are not directly damaged in glaucoma.

Amacrine cells (Option C): Amacrine cells are involved in the modulation of signals between bipolar and ganglion cells and are crucial for complex visual processing like motion detection. They are not selectively targeted in glaucomatous damage, although overall retinal dysfunction may occur in later stages.

Rods and Cones (Option D): Rods and cones are photoreceptors and remain relatively spared in glaucoma, especially in early stages.

questions.text: The site for maximum resistance in the Trabecular pathway is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Aqueous humor exits the eye primarily via the trabecular (conventional) pathway, which includes:
    • Trabecular meshwork → Schlemm's canal → Collector channels → Episcleral veins
    • This accounts for about 90% of aqueous outflow.
  • The maximum resistance to aqueous outflow occurs at the juxtacanalicular connective tissue (JCT), also known as the cribriform layer, located just adjacent to the inner wall of Schlemm's canal.
  • This region lacks large open pores and requires the aqueous to traverse tight extracellular spaces and endothelial cells of Schlemm's canal, making it the primary site of resistance under normal physiological conditions.
  • Unconventional or Uveoscleral pathway:
    • Accounts for the remaining 10% aqueous outflow:
      • Ciliary body→ Suprachoroidal space → → Episcleral veins/ Vortex veins

Explanation of other options:

Uveal part of TM (Option A): This is the innermost part of TM with loosely arranged collagen beams. It offers minimal resistance and allows relatively free flow of aqueous.

Corneoscleral part of TM (Option B): Located between the uveal and juxtacanalicular parts, it has moderate resistance.

questions.text: Tonometry in irregular corneas can be done by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Mackay-Marg tonometer (on which the Tono-Pen is based) is well-suited for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP) in irregular corneas, such as those affected by scarring, edema, or post-surgical changes.
  • It uses a small plunger and footplate to applanate the cornea and transmits readings electronically.
  • It is less influenced by corneal irregularities compared to Goldmann Applanation Tonometry (GAT), making it a preferred option in such cases.

Tonometry is the assessment of intraocular pressure (IOP), an essential component in the diagnosis and monitoring of glaucoma.

Types of Tonometry

Explanation of other options:

Rebound Tonometer (Option B): Uses a small probe that rebounds off the cornea. Useful in children and home settings, it does not require anesthesia, but accuracy is affected by corneal biomechanics. Less preferred for irregular corneas compared to Mackay-Marg.

Draeger Tonometer (Option C): Not widely used or considered standard in irregular corneas. Its mechanism and application are not clearly established in standard references for this specific use.

Maklakov Tonometer (Option D): An older applanation tonometer that uses a weight and dye to imprint on the cornea. Accuracy is strongly affected by corneal curvature and integrity. Not suitable for irregular or scarred corneas.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/805582/

questions.text: Name the Tonometer with variation in Applanation Surface
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Maklakov tonometer is a type of applanation tonometer with a variable applanation area (A) and fixed force (F).
  • This differs from most applanation tonometers that typically use a fixed area.
  • It is a contact tonometer and requires staining to assess the flattened corneal area.

Tonometry is the assessment of intraocular pressure (IOP), an essential component in the diagnosis and monitoring of glaucoma.

Types of Tonometry

Explanation of other options:

Mackay-Marg Tonometry (Option A): Used in irregular corneas. Measures IOP electronically using a plunger and strain gauge; fixed area but not known for variable surface.

Rebound Tonometer (Option B): Used for home or pediatric/self-tonometry. Works by bouncing a probe off the cornea and is independent of applanation area.

Draeger Tonometer (Option C): Less commonly used now; not associated with variable applanation surface. Measures intraocular pressure using rebound and indentation principles.

questions.text: Of the following, which one is a self-tonometer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rebound Tonometer (also known as iCare Tonometer) is a self-use or home tonometer, designed for patients to monitor intraocular pressure (IOP) on their own.
  • It works on the principle of rebound technology: a 8 mm plastic-tipped probe on a stainless steel wire is released by an electromagnetic field to strike the cornea and rebound.
  • The degree of deceleration after impact correlates with IOP - greater deceleration = higher IOP.
  • It does not require anesthesia and is portable, making it ideal for children or frequent home monitoring.

Explanation of other options:

Perkins Tonometer (Option A): A handheld version of the Goldmann applanation tonometer. Used in clinics and bedside settings, but not for self-use.

Dynamic Contour Tonometer (Pascal) (Option C): A contact tonometer with a contour-matching sensor. Known for high accuracy, but it is not portable or suitable for self-tonometry.

Maklakov Tonometer (Option D): An applanation tonometer that uses a variable surface area and a fixed weight. Requires corneal staining and is used clinically, not for self-measurement.

questions.text: The Gold Standard for measuring pressure in glaucoma patients is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Goldmann Applanation Tonometer (GAT) is the gold standard method for intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement in glaucoma patients.

Principle: Based on the Imbert-Fick law-

Pressure inside a sphere = Force required to flatten / Area flattened.

Mechanism: Measures the force required to flatten a fixed corneal area (3.06 mm diameter) using a prism tip and fluorescein staining.

Advantages:

  • Considered the gold standard for IOP measurement
  • Widely used
  • Reproducible and reliable in normal corneas

Disadvantages:

  • Not reliable in: Irregular or scarred corneas
  • Affected by operator bias
  • Influenced by scleral rigidity

Explanation of other options:

Schiotz Tonometer (Option A): The Schiotz tonometer is an indentation tonometer that measures IOP based on the depth of corneal indentation by a plunger. It is affected by scleral rigidity and is less accurate, making it unsuitable as a gold standard.

Tonopen (Option C): Tonopen is a handheld applanation tonometer used in irregular corneas and pediatric or supine patients. However, its accuracy is slightly lower than Goldmann's and can vary with operator technique.

Pascal's DCT (Option D): Pascal's DCT uses a contour-matching principle and is less influenced by corneal thickness. Though highly accurate, it is expensive and not as widely available as GAT.

Goldman applanation tonometer

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct gonioscopy lens
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Koeppe lens is used for direct gonioscopy.
  • It provides a direct view of the angle structures using a microscope.
  • The patient lies in a supine position during the examination.

Other lenses that are used in Direct gonioscopy:

  • Richardson-Shaffer
  • Layden
  • Hoskins-Barkan
  • Swan-Jacob
  • Thorpe
  • Wurst

Gonioscopy is a diagnostic technique used to visualize the anterior chamber angle of the eye (i.e., where the cornea meets the iris), which is critical for glaucoma diagnosis, classification, and management.

Types of Gonioscopy:

Structures Seen on Gonioscopy (from anterior to posterior):

Iris root → Ciliary body → Scleral spur → Trabecular meshwork → Schwalbe's line

(Mnemonic "I Can See The Structures Clearly")

Shaffer Angle Grading System:

Common Gonioscopic Findings and Their Associations:

Clinical Uses of Gonioscopy:

  • Diagnose open vs. closed-angle glaucoma
  • Identify peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS)
  • Evaluate for angle recession after trauma
  • Visualize neovascularization of the angle
  • Detect pseudoexfoliation, pigment dispersion
  • Pre-op evaluation before laser iridotomy or surgery
  • Check blood in Schlemm's canal (suggests ↑ EVP)

questions.text: Angle evaluation can be done by
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • Gonioscopy is the clinical gold standard for evaluating the anterior chamber angle, especially for glaucoma assessment.
  • AS-OCT (Anterior Segment Optical Coherence Tomography) provides non-contact, high-resolution cross-sectional images of the angle structures.
  • UBM (Ultrasound Biomicroscopy) uses high-frequency ultrasound to visualize anterior segment structures, including the angle, especially in opaque corneas or behind the iris.

questions.text: Schwalbe's line is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Schwalbe's line marks the termination of Descemet's membrane and the beginning of the trabecular meshwork.
  • Embryologically, it is where Descemet's membrane fuses with the trabecular beams as the endothelium and trabecular meshwork mature.
  • Gonioscopically, it is the most anterior structure seen and serves as a landmark for angle grading.

Structures Seen on Gonioscopy (from anterior to posterior):

Iris root → Ciliary body → Scleral spur → Trabecular meshwork → Schwalbe's line

(Mnemonic "I Can See The Structures Clearly")

questions.text: Identify the type of scotoma
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A Bjerrum (arcuate) scotoma is an arc-shaped visual field defect that begins at the blind spot and curves around the fixation point following the retinal nerve fiber layer.
  • It typically occurs in early glaucoma and respects the horizontal meridian.
  • This region corresponds to the Bjerrum's area-10°-20° from fixation, where glaucomatous damage is most commonly observed.
  • Arcuate scotomas are among the earliest and most classic glaucomatous defects and are used to identify progression over time.

Progression of Visual Field Defects in POAG

  1. Isopter contraction - Early diffuse generalized constriction of the central and peripheral fields.
  2. Baring of blind spot - Early non-specific sign due to inward curve of the outer boundary of the 30° field.
  3. Paracentral scotoma - Common early localized defect near fixation.
  4. Seidel scotoma - A sickle-shaped extension of the blind spot into arcuate regions.
  5. Nasal step of Roenne - Defect respecting horizontal midline due to selective damage of arcuate fibers.
  6. Arcuate (Bjerrum) scotoma - Classic mid-stage defect that arches from the blind spot toward the nasal field.
  7. Ring scotoma - Late stage, due to merging of superior and inferior arcuate scotomas.
  8. Tubular and temporal island - Seen in end-stage glaucoma; central and temporal islands may be all that remain.

Explanation of other options:

Paracentral scotoma (Option A): This is a small localized visual field defect that lies just adjacent to the fixation point, usually within 10°. It can occur in early glaucoma but does not extend from the blind spot or form an arc. It is usually more localized and not shaped like a bow or arc.

Ring scotoma (Option B): A ring scotoma is a complete or incomplete ring-shaped area of visual loss that surrounds the central field. Commonly seen in retinal dystrophies such as retinitis pigmentosa or in cases involving panretinal degeneration. In contrast to arcuate scotoma, it is not linked to nerve fiber layer loss or glaucoma and typically affects both nasal and temporal fields symmetrically.

Seidel scotoma (Option D): It is a comet-shaped extension of the blind spot. It is often seen in early glaucoma and represents a nasal step defect extending from the blind spot. Unlike arcuate scotomas, Seidel scotomas are smaller and more focal, often a precursor to arcuate defects.

questions.text: What would be the most important finding suggestive of glaucoma in a patient with elevated intraocular pressure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • While cup-to-disc (C:D) ratio alone has limited diagnostic sensitivity, the presence of a neuroretinal rim notchindicates focal axonal damage, which is highly specific to glaucomatous optic neuropathy.
  • In glaucoma, the pattern of rim loss (especially notching) is more critical than the absolute size of the cup.
  • The finding becomes more significant in the context of elevated IOP.

Fundus Findings in Glaucoma:

Explanation of other options:

Bilateral cup to disc ratio of 0.7 (Option A): Not diagnostic by itself. Large optic discs can have physiologically large cups, especially if symmetric. Must assess other features like rim thinning or disc hemorrhage.

Disc ratio asymmetry of 0.1 (Option B): A CDR asymmetry >0.2 is concerning for glaucoma. Asymmetry of 0.1 may be within normal limits.

Very deep optic cup (Option C): Cup depth is not a reliable standalone parameter for glaucoma. Shallow or deep cups can be seen in normal or glaucomatous eyes. Structural changes in the rim are more predictive.

questions.text: According to the Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study (OHTS), which one of the following is associated with an increased risk of converting from ocular hypertension to primary open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study (OHTS) was a pivotal multicenter randomized trial evaluating whether topical ocular hypotensive therapy can prevent or delay the onset of primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) in patients with ocular hypertension.

Key risk factors for progression to POAG (as per OHTS):

  • Thinner central corneal thickness (CCT ≤ 555 µm)
  • Higher intraocular pressure (IOP)
  • Larger vertical cup-to-disc ratio
  • Older age
  • Higher pattern standard deviation (PSD) on visual field testing

Incidence of POAG over 5 years:

  • 5% in the untreated group
  • 4% in the treated group (topical ocular hypotensive medication)

Explanation of other options:

Family history of angle-closure glaucoma (Option A): Incorrect. The OHTS focuses on primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). A family history of angle-closure glaucomais not associated with increased POAG risk

A history of diabetes mellitus (Option B): Incorrect. In fact, diabetes was found to be a negative risk factor in OHTS.

Smaller cup disc ratio (Option D): Incorrect. It is actually a larger vertical cup-disc ratio that is associated with increased POAG risk.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12049574/

questions.text: Which of the following may cause erroneously low measurements of intraocular pressure by Goldmann applanation tonometry?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Goldmann applanation tonometer measures the force necessary to flatten an area of the cornea that is 3.06 mm in diameter.
  • It is based on the Imbert-Fick principle, which states that the pressure inside an ideal sphere equals the force necessary to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening. There are multiple possible sources of error in tonometry.
  • Squeezing the eyelids and pressure on the globe can falsely elevate IOP.
  • Excessive fluorescein results in wide mires and an inaccurately high reading, whereas inadequate fluorescein leads to low readings.
  • Increased central corneal thickness may produce artificially high IOP measurements, and decreased central corneal thickness may give an artificially low IOP.

questions.text: Which of the following is a late visual field defect in Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ring scotoma is considered a late-stage field defect in POAG. It occurs due to coalescence of arcuate scotomas that encircle the central vision, sparing only a small island of central field.
  • It typically signals advanced glaucomatous damage and corresponds with extensive retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) and optic nerve head loss.

Progression of Visual Field Defects in POAG

  • Isopter contraction - Early diffuse generalized constriction of the central and peripheral fields.
  • Baring of blind spot - Early non-specific sign due to inward curve of the outer boundary of the 30° field.
  • Paracentral scotoma - Common early localized defect, especially seen in Bjerrum's area (10°-20° from fixation). (Option A ruled out)
  • Seidel scotoma - A sickle-shaped extension of the blind spot into arcuate regions.
  • Nasal step of Roenne - Defect respecting horizontal midline due to selective damage of arcuate fibers. (Option B ruled out)
  • Arcuate (Bjerrum) scotoma - Classic mid-stage defect that arches from the blind spot toward the nasal field. (Option C ruled out)
  • Ring scotoma - Late stage, due to merging of superior and inferior arcuate scotomas.
  • Tubular and temporal island - Seen in end-stage glaucoma; central and temporal islands may be all that remain.

questions.text: What is the investigation being done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows Optic Nerve Head (ONH) and Retinal Nerve Fiber Layer (RNFL) analysis done using Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT).

It includes:

  • RNFL thickness and deviation maps
  • RNFL quadrant and clock-hour plots
  • Neuro-retinal rim thickness graph
  • Extracted horizontal and vertical tomograms

RNFL analysis provides a quantitative estimation of the thickness of the retinal nerve fiber layer, which contains the axons of retinal ganglion cells and is often thinned in glaucoma.

A normal RNFL thickness is usually ≥80 µm.

  • 70-79 µm is suspicious.
  • 60-69 µm implies possible glaucoma (seen in <5% of normals).
  • In this image, OS (left eye) has an average RNFL thickness of 55 µm, which is strongly suggestive of glaucomatous damage.

Explanation of other options:

Blue on yellow perimetry (Option B): A specialized visual field test that detects early glaucomatous field loss by targeting the short-wavelength (blue) sensitive pathways. It does not produce structural images like the one shown.

White on red perimetry (Option C): Not a standard test in glaucoma or RNFL assessment.

Laser interferometry (Option D): Used for assessing visual potential (e.g., in dense cataracts), not structural imaging of the RNFL

questions.text: What is the investigation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows a low spatial frequency sinusoidal grating undergoing high temporal frequency counterphase flicker (>15 Hz), which produces the frequency doubling illusion-the stripes appear to double in number.
  • This phenomenon is the basis of Frequency Doubling Technology (FDT) Perimetry.
  • It is used as a pre-perimetric glaucoma screening tool, especially sensitive to early glaucomatous changes.

Frequency Doubling Perimetry (FDP)

Principle:

  • FDP is based on a visual illusion where a low spatial frequency sinusoidal grating flickers at a high temporal frequency (>15 Hz).
  • This creates a frequency doubling illusion: the grating appears to have twice the number of bars as it actually does.

Mechanism:

  • The flicker produces a nonlinear response in certain retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), specifically the magnocellular (M) cells.
  • These large-diameter M cells are thought to be preferentially damaged early in glaucoma.

Clinical Use:

  • FDP is a pre-perimetric functional test that detects early glaucomatous changes before visual field defects appear on standard automated perimetry.
  • It is fast, inexpensive, and easy to administer, making it useful for screening and early detection of glaucoma.

Significance:

  • FDP allows early identification of functional loss in glaucoma by targeting specific vulnerable ganglion cell pathways, which is critical for timely intervention.

Explanation of other options:

RNFL analysis (Option A): Uses OCT to measure retinal nerve fiber layer thickness, provides structural data-not functional/perceptual response as in FDT.

Blue on yellow perimetry (SWAP) (Option B): Tests koniocellular pathway, sensitive to blue light. Uses blue stimuli on yellow background. Another pre-perimetric test for early glaucoma, but the stimulus and mechanism differ.

Laser interferometry (Option D): Estimates visual acuity potential, especially in media opacities. Not related to perimetry or ganglion cell testing.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pre-perimetric analysis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glaucoma hemifield test is part of Standard Automated Perimetry (SAP), especially the Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer.
  • It compares five sectors above and below the horizontal meridian to detect field asymmetry-a hallmark of glaucomatous damage.
  • It is a diagnostic endpoint in studies like the Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study (OHTS).
  • Requires measurable field loss, making it a perimetric indicator-not suitable for pre-perimetric detection.

Pre-perimetric glaucoma tests aim to detect structural or functional changes before standard visual field defects become evident on Standard Automated Perimetry (SAP).

Pre-perimetric Investigations:

  • SWAP (Short Wavelength Automated Perimetry): Detects damage to blue-yellow (koniocellular) pathways, useful in early glaucoma. (Option A ruled out)
  • Scanning Laser Polarimetry: Quantifies RNFL thickness using polarization properties of light. (Option B ruled out)
  • RNFL OCT: Provides quantitative imaging of nerve fiber layer thinning and optic nerve head changes before visual field loss. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Air-cornea critical angle is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • When light travels from a denser medium (like the cornea) to a less dense medium (like air), some of the light is bent (refracted) and some is reflected.
  • If the angle of incidence becomes too large, all the light is reflected back inside the cornea. This is called Total Internal Reflection.
  • The critical angle is the maximum angle at which light can escape - beyond this, all light is reflected.

Formula: Using Snell's Law:

Where:

  • n1 = refractive index of cornea ≈ 1.376
  • n2 = refractive index of air ≈ 1.0

So,

  • In a slit lamp, the light rays from the anterior chamber angle hit the cornea-air interface at an angle greater than 46°.
  • This causes total internal reflection, so we can't see the angle directly.
  • Gonioscopy uses a goniolens (which touches the cornea and has a similar refractive index) to remove the cornea-air interface.
  • This allows light to pass through instead of reflecting back - making angle structures visible.

Reference: https://www.aao.org/education/disease-review/principles-of-gonioscopy

questions.text: Transpalpebral tonometer is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Diaton tonometer is a transpalpebral tonometer, which measures intraocular pressure (IOP) through the upper eyelid, without contacting the cornea.
  • No anesthesia or sterilization is needed.

Useful in:

  • Eyes with corneal prostheses
  • Severe corneal scarring/irregularity
  • Uncooperative patients

Limitations:

  • Readings are less reliable than Goldmann
  • Corneal thickness significantly affects values

Explanation of other options:

Schiotz (Option A): This is an indentation tonometer that measures intraocular pressure by directly pressing on the cornea using a weighted plunger. Requires direct contact with the cornea and cannot be used through the eyelid.

Perkin (Option B): Perkin is a handheld applanation tonometer that measures IOP by flattening the cornea, based on the Imbert-Fick principle. Requires corneal contact, fluorescein, and topical anesthesia.

Goldmann (Option C): Goldmann Applanation Tonometry is the gold standard for measuring IOP, done via a slit lamp by flattening a specific corneal area. It cannot be used transpalpebrally and needs a clear cornea and topical anesthesia.

questions.text: The Van Herrick method is for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Van Herick method is a non-contact slit lamp technique used to estimate the peripheral anterior chamber depth (ACD)-a key parameter in assessing angle closure risk.

Setup:

  • A narrow, bright slit beam is directed at the temporal limbus at a 60° angle to the cornea.
  • The viewing arm is perpendicular to the cornea.
  • Use 15x magnification on the slit lamp.

Assessment:

  • The beam creates an optical section showing both:
    • Corneal thickness (CT)
    • Space between the corneal endothelium and the iris (Peripheral ACD)

The ratio of the anterior chamber depth (PACD) to the corneal thickness (CT) determines the Van Herick grade.

Grades and Interpretation:


Clinical Signs:

  • In a deep anterior chamber, the slit beam reaches the opposite limbus, producing a clear optical section.
  • In a shallow anterior chamber, the forward bowing of the iris blocks the beam, creating a shadow on the medial iris, suggesting a narrow angle.

Other Methods of Measuring ACD (Objective):

  • Slit lamp pachymetry
  • Anterior Segment OCT
  • Scheimpflug imaging (Pentacam)
  • Orbscan II

Explanation of other options:

Viewing angle structures (Option A): This is done using gonioscopy, not the Van Herick method. Gonioscopy uses a goniolens to directly visualize the anterior chamber angle and identify structures like Schwalbe's line, trabecular meshwork, and scleral spur.

IOP measurement (Option C): Intraocular Pressure (IOP) is measured using tonometers such as Goldmann applanation tonometry, Schiotz, or non-contact tonometers. Van Herick does not provide any information about IOP.

Aqueous outflow drainage measurement (Option D): This refers to evaluating aqueous humor dynamics, often assessed via tonography or using imaging tools in advanced glaucoma diagnostics. The Van Herick method only estimates angle width indirectly based on anterior chamber depth, not the actual aqueous outflow function.

questions.text: Which part of the visual field is typically preserved until the late stages of Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), visual field loss progresses in a characteristic pattern, with early defects affecting the nasal field and areas around the blind spot.
  • As the disease advances, the central and temporal fields are typically preserved the longest.
  • Eventually, only a small temporal crescent and central island may remain before complete field loss occurs.

Progression of Visual Field Loss in POAG:

Explanation of other options:

Superior (Option A): The superior visual field is often affected early due to damage to the inferior retinal nerve fibers, resulting in superior arcuate defects.

Nasal (Option C): Nasal field defects (e.g., nasal step) are often the earliest to occur in glaucoma due to the anatomy of the retinal nerve fiber layer.

Inferior (Option D): Inferior field defects do occur, but are not the last to be preserved. In fact, superior retinal nerve fibers (serving the inferior field) are often more vulnerable.

questions.text: Fibers most susceptible to damage in high intraocular pressure (IOP) are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The arcuate nerve fibers originate from the superior and inferior retina and arch around the macula to insert into the superior and inferior poles of the optic disc.
  • These fibers pass through the superior and inferior regions of the lamina cribrosa, where mechanical stress from raised IOP is greatest.
  • The superior and inferior nerve fiber layers are also thicker, making them particularly vulnerable to glaucomatous damage.
  • This correlates with early Bjerrum/arcuate scotomas and nasal steps in the visual field.

Explanation of other options:

Nasal fibers (Option B): These travel directly from the nasal retina to the nasal disc. They are not typically involved early in glaucoma and are more resistant to pressure-related damage.

Macular fibers (Option C): These are central and typically spared until late-stage glaucoma. Damage here leads to central vision loss, which occurs after peripheral loss.

Papillomacular bundle( Option D): These small-caliber fibers run from the macula to the temporal disc. Like macular fibers, they are generally preserved until late in the disease and are not pressure-sensitive early on.
